pageData.text: In this investigation, students will observe and explore the effects of circular motion. Students will construct a <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> device and use it to find the <button class='glossary-text'>velocity</button> of a mass that, over a series of trials, is subjected to incrementally increased centripetal forces. Students must then analyze their data and explain how centripetal force is affected by mass and velocity.

text: Describe the effect of mass on .
Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>velocity</button> of an object in <button class='glossary-text'>uniform circular motion</button>.

pageData.text: One of the physical issues that astronauts experience when living in microgravity environments is a loss of muscle mass and bone density. Without Earth’s gravity, there is no resistant force to push against, stopping the physiological processes that maintain these structures.  To counteract this, scientists have proposed many ways of creating artificial gravity to allow humans to live in space for longer <button class='glossary-text'>periods</button> of time. One of the most common solutions seen in science fiction space stations is made of large spinning rings. While these designs may seem fantastic, they are based on the very real idea of <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> and the resulting <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button>. As the ring spins with its tangential <button class='glossary-text'>velocity</button>, the centripetal force would be directed in toward the central axis. Any humans in the space station would experience centripetal <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> in a similar way to the acceleration of gravity. Unfortunately, as of right now, these designs are impractical because the spinning ring would have to be extremely large and move too fast to create the acceleration needed. However, these principles have been applied on a much smaller scale in a variable gravity centrifuge to create artificial gravity for flight experiments on the International Space Station<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1McAllister, M. (2018, May 7). Multi-use variable-G platform arrives at International Space Station. NASA.
https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/news/Spinning_Science_MVP_Arrives_At_ISS

pageData.desc: An illustration of a fictional space station featuring a rotating ring structure.
pageData.altText: An illustration of a fictional space station featuring a rotating ring structure.

pageData.text: According to Newton’s first law of motion, is the tendency of an object to resist change to its motion unless acted upon by a net or unbalanced force. An object acted on by balanced forces will either remain motionless or move in a straight line at a constant speed. An unbalanced force will cause an object to accelerate or change . Velocity is a vector with both magnitude and direction. is a change in an object’s velocity. An object is accelerating if it is speeding up or slowing down or changing direction.

When an object moves in a constant speed in a circular path, it is said to be moving in . When an object moves in uniform circular motion there is a acting on the object. A centripetal force is a force acting on an object, directed toward the center of the object’s circular path.

When an object moves in a circular path, there is a tangential velocity directed 90 degrees from the radius. To satisfy the conditions for uniform circular motion, the tangential speed must be constant.

One example of uniform circular motion is to imagine twirling a ball or some mass on a string in a horizontal circle. If the (the time for the ball to make one revolution) is constant, then the tangential speed (v T) is constant (see Figure 1). However, the force of tension in the string pulls the ball toward the circle and constantly changes the direction of the ball. This creates an acceleration called . The centripetal acceleration is directed toward the center of the circle to align with the centripetal force.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A circle with two blue dots (indicating an object with mass), showing its centripetal acceleration and centripetal force.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A circle with two blue dots (indicating an object with mass), showing its centripetal acceleration and centripetal force.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between the period and tangential speed of an object in uniform circular motion?

options.text: If the period is constant, the tangential speed is constant.
The period is two times the tangential speed.
If the period is constant, the tangential speed is half the period.
If the period increases, the tangential speed decreases.
If the period decreases, the tangential speed increases.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the period (the time for the ball to make one revolution) is constant, then the tangential speed (vT ) is constant.

An important misconception to address is the notion of a centrifugal force. Centrifugal force is an apparent force that is perceived to push objects moving in a circular path radially outward. Imagine riding in an automobile that makes a sudden turn. A passenger in this situation might feel as if there is a force pulling them out of the car towards the outside of the turn. However, if the passenger is observed from a fixed position outside the car, it is apparent that the passenger was actually continuing on their original, straight path and the car turned around them. They are not being pulled from the passenger door, the passenger door has changed position, and is now on the outside of the turn.
The passenger door is, in fact, now providing a centripetal force, holding the person inside the car.

pageData.desc: How to Take a Picture Through a Microscope

pageData.text: In , an object with mass (m ) moves in uniform circular motion. The magnitude of the tangential (v T) remains constant, while the centripetal , directed toward the center of the circular path, causes the direction of the object to constantly change. Note that the tangential velocity is always at a right angle to the direction of the centripetal acceleration.
Note: A is a line that touches, but does not cross a curve. The tangent line to a circle is always perpendicular to the radius of the circle.

To calculate the tangential velocity of an object in uniform circular motion, you divide the circumference of the circle by time it takes to complete one revolution. Note that in , the magnitude of the tangential , represented by the length of the arrow labeled v T, does not change; however, the direction is altered by the . A person located at the position indicated by the blue circle (m) perceives this constant change in direction as a force directed outward from the center of the circle, but if the centripetal force were suddenly removed, the person or the object would not move radially outward from the circle but would continue in a direction tangential to the circular path. In Activity 1, you will perform a simple demonstration of a marble undergoing this motion and will see the tangential nature of its velocity when released.

Many of our everyday activities involve centripetal force. Try spinning a bucket full of water above your head! The water does not spill out due to centripetal force and <button class='glossary-text'>inertia</button>. When race car drivers zoom around a track, the curved portion of the tracks banked at angles increase the centripetal force on their tires due to friction to help them take those turns at high speeds. Anytime you experience turning, this is centripetal force at play. Carnival rides, swinging on a swing, and the moon revolving around the Earth all need forces to keep them accelerating centripetally.

pageData.question: In Activity 1, you will perform a simple demonstration with what object to investigate centripetal force?

pageData.question: If an object in circular motion, such as a marble, has its centripetal force removed, the object would move in which of the following ways?

options.text: The object would move along the tangent line to the circular path.
The object would continue following its circular path.
The object would follow a circular path wider than its original path.s
The object would move in reverse.
The object would follow a circular path smaller than its original path.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The object would continue in a direction tangential to the circular path. The tangent line to a circle is always perpendicular to the radius of the circle.

pageData.altText: A map of the workflow for the investigation. In Activity 1, set up the marble and cup. Then, move the marble in a circle in the cup. Next, release the cup. Then, observe the motion of the marble. In Activity 2, measure the mass of the bobber. Then, assemble the bobber and bag setup. Next, place the washer in the bag. Then, measure the mass of the washer and the bag. Next, record the time it takes to complete 30 revolutions. Then, calculate the time of one revolution. Repeat the process of measuring the mass of the washer and bag, calculating the time of one revolution, and adding an additional washer to the bag before each new trial. Once five trials have been completed, move on to Activity 3. In activity 3, calculate the centripetal force on the washers. Then, calculate the weight of the washers. Next, calculate the percent error between the centripetal force and the weight. Finally, repeat these calculations for all five trials.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.
Make sure the knots tied in the string are secure and perform the experiment where the spinning bobber will not strike any other person or object while spinning or if the knot or string fails.

Safety goggles should be worn during these activities, which involve the movement and <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> of objects. Take care during the execution of these activities to avoid injuring eyes due to spinning objects.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Alternate Methods for Collecting Data Using Digital Devices Much of the uncertainty in physics experiments arises from human reaction time error in measuring the times of events. Some of the time intervals are very short, which increases the effect of human error due to reaction time.

Observing the experiment from a good vantage point that removes parallax errors and recording measurements for multiple trials helps to minimize error; using a digital device as an alternate method of data collection may further minimize error. Many digital devices, such as smartphones and tablets, have cameras and software that allow the user to pause or slow down the video. If you film the activity against a scale such as a tape measure, you can use your video playback program to record position and time data. This can provide more accurate data and may eliminate the need for multiple trials.

If the time on your device’s playback program is not sufficiently accurate, you may download an app such as the following free apps:
  • OnForm
    iOS and Android
  • SloPro
    iOS
    Android
Or you may upload the video to your computer. Your operating system or software suite may include video playback programs, or these programs may be available for download.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a vector quantity?
Which of the following units is equivalent to a Newton (N)?
An object is travelling in uniform circular motion. What is the direction of the centripetal force on the object?

options.text: toward the center of the object’s circular path
away from the center of the object’s circular path
tangential to the object’s circular path in the direction it is travelling
tangential to the object’s circular path in the opposite direction as it is travelling
toward the center of the Earth

assestmentData.question: A person is riding in a car when the car goes around a tight curve. The person feels like there is a force pushing them into the car door. What is causing this sensation?

options.text: Their inertia continues to move them forward as the car turns around them.
Their centrifugal force pushes them outward.
The centripetal force of the car door pushes them inward.
Their centrifugal force pushes them inward.
The force of gravity pulls them downward.

assestmentData.question: If the mass of an object moving in uniform circular motion doubles, but the velocity is kept the same, what will happen to the centripetal force on that object?

A 50 kg child swings on a merry-go-round at a point 4.0 m from the center (radius). If the time it takes for the merry-go-round to rotate once is 10 seconds, what is the centripetal force felt by the child?
Which of the following is NOT a safety consideration for this lab?

Take care during the execution of these activities to avoid injuring eyes due to spinning objects.

Make sure the knots tied in the string are secure and perform the experiment where the spinning bobber will not strike any other person or object while spinning or if the knot or string fails.

assestmentData.question: What role do the washers in the bag play in this experiment?

options.text: They act as a weight, providing a balancing force to the tension in the string.
They act as the mass undergoing uniform circular motion.
They act as an anchor to keep the radius constant.
They act as the centripetal force on the bobber.
They act as a measuring device, allowing you to calculate the period of rotation.

assestmentData.question: A mass is travelling in uniform circular motion around a 1 m circumference. It does 30 revolutions in 15 seconds. What is the tangential velocity of the mass?

Read through all assigned activities carefully.
Clean the work space.
In Activity 1, you will use a marble in a cup to create circular motion, then release the marble to observe tangential <button class='glossary-text'>velocity</button>.
Collect a blue marble and a plastic culture cup from the mechanics module kit.
Place the cup upside down over the blue marble as seen in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A blue marble with a clear plastic culture cup turned over on top of it.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A blue marble with a clear plastic culture cup turned over on top of it.

pageData.text: Using a permanent marker, draw a dot on the bottom of the cup near the edge.
Move the cup in a circular path so that the blue marble travels around the rim of the cup.
While the marble is still rolling around the perimeter of the cup, quickly lift the cup straight up as the marble crosses the dot you drew on the edge of the cup.
Observe the direction of the marble as the cup is removed.
Note: If possible, capture a video of the marble as the cup is removed and watch at slow speed. See the “Technology” section for more information on collecting data with digital devices.

In Activity 2, you will construct a <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> device and use it to find the <button class='glossary-text'>velocity</button> of a mass that, over a series of trials, is subjected to incrementally increased centripetal forces. You will collect data that will be analyzed in Activity 3.

pages.title:
A
 Effect of Mass and Velocity on Centripetal Force (15 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Effect of Mass and Velocity on Centripetal Force (15 steps)

typeBefore.text: In Activity 2, you will construct a device to verify the equation for . Washers are added to a plastic bag suspended from a string which passes through a small, plastic tube. The opposite end of the string is attached to a fishing bobber, which will act as the mass undergoing . The plastic tube will allow you to hold the device and spin the bobber in a circle. The washers in the plastic bag act as a weight, providing a balancing force to the tension in the string. As masses are added to the bag, the centripetal force acting on the bobber changes, requiring an adjustment to either the radius or the tangential . In this experiment, the radius is kept constant; therefore, the velocity of the bobber must increase to support the suspended weight as more washers are added to the bag.

pageData.text: Cut a piece of string approximately 100 cm in length.
Using the pocket electronic balance, measure the mass of the bobber in grams. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Using a pencil or pair of scissors, create a hole in the plastic bag at the top, beneath the plastic seal, in the center (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A clear resealable plastic bag with a small white string looped through the center of the bag.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A clear resealable plastic bag with a small white string looped through the center of the bag.

pageData.text: Thread one end of the string through the hole in the plastic bag. Tie the end of the string to itself in a double knot just above the top of the bag. Make sure that the string is tied securely.
Thread the other end of the string through the narrow plastic tube.

Tie this end of the string in a double knot through the hoop in the top of the bobber. Make sure that the string is tied securely. To access the hook, press in the red button on the bobber. This is where the forefinger is, as seen in Figure 4.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A red and white fishing bobber with a white string looped through its hook.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A red and white fishing bobber with a white string looped through its hook.

pageData.text: Place the center of the bobber at the 0 point on the ruler and pull the string out to the 30 cm mark.

Using the marker, mark the string at the 30 cm point as seen in Figure 5. Make sure that the mark is on both sides of the string at the 30 cm point. This is the radius (r ) of the circle. Record this measurement in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A red and white fishing bobber with a string looped through the hook end. A plastic tube is running through the string.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A red and white fishing bobber with a string looped through the hook end. A plastic tube is running through the string.

pageData.text: Slide the plastic tube so that the end closest to the bobber is aligned with the black marking on the string.
Make a second black mark on the string at the other end of the plastic tube. This gives a second reference point during the activity. The overall assembly should look like Figure 6.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: The complete assembly for Activity 2, which shows a clear plastic bag with a white string looped through the top; on the other end of the string is a red and white fishing bobber; a plastic tube sits in the middle.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: The complete assembly for Activity 2, which shows a clear plastic bag with a white string looped through the top; on the other end of the string is a red and white fishing bobber; a plastic tube sits in the middle.

pageData.text: Place one large washer in the bag. Use the balance to measure the total mass in grams of the bag with the washer. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Hold the narrow plastic tube and begin to swing the bobber in a horizontal circular path above your head. The 30 cm mark should be even with the top edge of the narrow tube.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Use a timer to record (in seconds) the time it takes for the bobber to make 30 revolutions. It may take some practice to find a technique to accurately count the revolutions of the bobber. Record this time in Data Table 1.
Find time for one revolution by dividing the time measured for 30 revolutions by 30. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Repeat Steps 11–14 for the other trials listed in Data Table 1. Add washers as needed for each trial.

In Activity 3, you will use the data from Activity 2 and the equation for <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> to calculate the centripetal force for each trial. You will also compare the calculated weight of the washers to their measured weight and calculate the percent error.

typeBefore.text: As you perform the following calculations, note any correlation you see between the mass of the washers, the , and the . Record all values in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: Convert masses measured in grams to kilograms by dividing by 1,000.
Convert lengths measured in centimeters into meters by dividing by 100.
Using the radius (r), calculate the circumference (c ) of the circle. Recall that c = 2πr, and that π = 3.14.
Calculate the tangential velocity of the bobber. Use the equationv = d/t ,where v is the velocity, d is the circumference, and t is the time for one revolution, or the .

Calculate the centripetal force exerted on the bobber by the tension in the string for each trial. Use the equationFc = mv 2/r,where Fc is the magnitude of the centripetal force, m is the mass of the bobber, v 2 is the square of the tangential velocity of the bobber, and r is the radius of the bobber’s circular path.
Calculate the weight of the washers. Weight = mass × due to gravity (g = 9.8 m/s2): W = mg

Calculate the percent error between the weight of the washers for each trial and the magnitude of the centripetal force calculated in Step 5. Your experimental value is the centripetal force, and the theoretical value is the weight of the washers calculated in Step 6.
percent error = | experimental - theoretical | /theoretical × 100%

What do you notice about the relationship between the centripetal force and the weight of the cylinder with washers?  Explain the reason for this relationship.
How will centripetal force be affected if you double the velocity at which you spin the sphere?
What would you expect to happen to the velocity of the bobber if the mass of the washers in the cylinder remained the same and the radius was doubled?

data.title: Acceleration
data.content: A change in an object’s velocity

data.title: Centripetal acceleration (ac )
data.content: Acceleration directed toward the center of the circle to align with the centripetal force

data.title: Centripetal force (Fc )
data.content: A force acting on an object, directed toward the center of the object’s circular path

data.title: Inertia
data.content: The tendency of an object to resist change to its motion unless acted upon by a net or unbalanced force

data.title: Period
data.content: The time for an object to complete one revolutione

data.title: Tangent line
data.content: A line that touches, but does not cross, a curve

data.title: Uniform circular motion
data.content: When an object moves in a constant speed in a circular path

data.title: Velocity
data.content: The rate of change of the position of an object; it refers to both the speed and direction of an object; it is a vector quantity
